keyTakeAways: The Louvre Museum has faced multiple security breaches, including a recent heist in October 2025 involving high-value jewelry, such as the damaged crown of Empress Eugénie.
The museum's aging infrastructure, including outdated security systems and poor climate control, has contributed to vulnerabilities and increased risks of theft and damage.
The Louvre has a long history of art thefts, including the 1911 disappearance of the 'Mona Lisa' and the 1983 theft of Renaissance armor, which were returned in 2021.
Overcrowding and understaffing have led to deteriorating visitor experience and have created conditions that endanger the conservation of artworks.
French officials, including President Emmanuel Macron, have responded to these issues with plans to expand the museum and provide dedicated spaces, such as a new room for the 'Mona Lisa'.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Louvre Museum in Paris suffered a brazen daylight heist in October 2025, during which thieves stole jewelry of immense value, including the crown of Empress Eugénie, which was found damaged outside the museum. The incident, which occurred in just seven minutes, underscores a long-standing issue of inadequate security systems and outdated infrastructure. A Court of Auditors report from 2019 to 2024 identified persistent delays in updating security and operational failures, while a 2025 memo from Louvre president Laurence des Cars warned of deteriorating conditions, overcrowding, and poor conservation. This heist is part of a pattern of thefts, including the 1911 disappearance of the Mona Lisa and the 1983 theft of Renaissance armor, which were returned in 2021. The museum, which welcomed 8.7 million visitors last year, has faced ongoing challenges with visitor capacity, staff shortages, and climate control, prompting President Emmanuel Macron to announce plans for a major expansion and the creation of a dedicated room for the Mona Lisa.
title: Jewelry Heist at the Louvre Is Latest Problem to Beset France’s Most Famous Museum
